race.name: Gravel Roll - Pecan Shaker
race.tagline: Rolling Georgia gravel in central Georgia's Hawkinsville.

climate.description: Variable conditions with heat possible in spring, cool possible in fall, and humidity.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through rolling central Georgia. Moderate elevation with rural scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional Georgia event. Rolling terrain is moderate but small town location and limited organization.

biased_opinion.summary: Gravel Roll - Pecan Shaker is a regional event in Hawkinsville, central Georgia. The rolling terrain offers moderate climbing with rural scenery, but the small town location, limited amenities, and moderate organization keep it firmly in Tier 3. Hawkinsville is a small town with limited lodging and dining. It's a solid regional event for Georgia cyclists.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional Georgia gravel race with rolling terrain. Worth it for Georgia cyclists seeking a local event. Not a destination race for out-of-state travelers.

final_verdict.one_liner: Rolling Georgia gravel in central Georgia's Hawkinsville.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in Georgia and want a local rolling gravel event—yes, it's a solid regional race. If you're from out of state—there are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Southeast events: Gravel Worlds, Pisgah Monster-Cross, Hot Springs Gravel Gauntlet. For similar regional events: other Georgia gravel races.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Hawkinsville has limited lodging. Macon has more options.
logistics.food: Small town with limited dining. Stock nutrition.

course_description.character: Rolling Georgia gravel with moderate climbing.
course_description.signature_challenge: Rolling Georgia gravel in central Georgia.

non_negotiables.why: Rolling Georgia terrain requires sustained effort.
Georgia spring/fall means heat and humidity are possible.
Small town location requires self-sufficiency and preparation.

topics.heat: Racing in Georgia heat and humidity

marketplace_variables.race_hook: Rolling Georgia gravel in central Georgia's Hawkinsville.

logistics.explanation: Start location at 42 South Lumpkin St in Hawkinsville is consistent across sources, with 300-rider field size and multiple distance options (41, 72, 106 miles). Law enforcement and course marshals provide key intersection support including 'rolling enclosure out of town,' though detailed parking and packet pickup information remains unavailable.

length.explanation: Three distance options accommodate different riders: 41-mile short course, 72-mile intermediate, and 106-mile long course. The timed-segment format covers only 30-50% of each course distance, allowing riders to 'take advantage of being able to ride with friends of different fitness and skill levels' during untimed sections. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: Course features 'Georgia red clay, red dirt, white kaolin, loam, dust over crust, and of course....the loose stuff' across diverse agricultural terrain. Officially rated as 'difficult terrain with longer, steeper hills,' the varied surface conditions through pecan groves and timberlands provide moderate technical challenges. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: The 'longer, steeper hills' mentioned in official descriptions align with the 3,000 feet over 75 miles, creating sustained climbing through Georgia's rolling agricultural landscape. Terrain includes passages through fish hatcheries, private timberlands, and crop fields with consistent elevation changes rather than dramatic peaks. Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 78°F and lows of 58°F, with a 21% chance of rain on any given day. Samson Large reported that 'Pecan Shaker 2024 wasn't without tragedy, as we did have quite the rain before raceday, making for soggy conditions on certain areas of the course.' The event moved from fall to spring in 2024 due to scheduling conflicts, with one rider requiring medical attention during challenging conditions. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Central Georgia terrain near sea level eliminates any altitude considerations. The course travels through low-elevation agricultural areas including watermelon, sunflower and peanut fields with no meaningful elevation above sea level to impact performance. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Riders 'speed past pecan groves and through fish hatcheries, private timberlands, watermelon, sunflower and peanut fields' on terrain similar to the Bird Dog 100 course. The diverse agricultural setting provides scenic variety across Georgia's rural landscape, though the adventure factor remains focused on pastoral touring rather than wilderness exploration.

prestige.explanation: Samson Large describes the philosophy: 'Whether you're on the podium, or coming in DFL, the gravel roll is really about the vibes. Having a good time with friends of all skills, ages, backgrounds, and bikes.' The event emphasizes community over competition, with organizers stating their 'community-focused races leave traditional-format gravel grinders in the dust.'

race_quality.explanation: Private on-course medical support and roving mechanical assistance provide solid infrastructure, with organizers emphasizing 'we aren't solely relying on 911 to help us.' The timed-segment format covers 30-50% of course distance, though basic organizational details like entry fees and detailed course information remain unavailable.

experience.explanation: Fully stocked aid stations feature electrolyte mix from S.O.S Hydration and food, with post-race entertainment and community raffle. Organizers prioritize that 'your safety while on course is always our #1 priority' while maintaining the 'Super Serious Good Times' atmosphere with finisher awards for all participants.

community.explanation: The event maintains strong local support with 'a huge shoutout to the town of Hawkinsville for being such great hosts each year.' Samson Large emphasizes the inclusive atmosphere: 'We all love cracking a cold one after the ride and sharing stories from the trail' with riders of all skills, ages, backgrounds, and bikes welcome.

field_depth.explanation: Field limited to 300 riders with age group categories and open divisions receiving podium prizes. The 'no gravel bike? No worries!' philosophy and community-focused approach attracts recreational riders rather than elite competitive fields, though all participants remain eligible for the community raffle and finisher awards. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100.

value.explanation: Entry fees unavailable, but included amenities are substantial: private medical support, roving mechanical assistance, fully stocked aid stations, post-race food and entertainment, community raffle, and finisher awards for all participants. The timed-segment format provides competitive elements without requiring full-distance racing commitment.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $60-100. Hawkinsville, Georgia offers small-town lodging and dining costs without destination pricing. The event provides 'a huge shoutout to the town of Hawkinsville for being such great hosts each year,' suggesting local community support that typically translates to reasonable accommodation options for visiting riders. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners
